awd_titl_txt: TWC: Medium: Designing Strongly Obfuscated Hardware with Quantifiable Security against Reverse Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Our world has become increasingly reliant on integrated circuits (ICs). Mobile phones are deeply enmeshed in our everyday lives, we drive cars equipped with hundreds of ICs, and have come to depend on the power grid and other cyber physical systems that are controlled by ICs. Not surprisingly, the issue of securing hardware has become increasingly vital. A reverse engineering adversary may, for example, be motivated by extracting intellectual property from a circuit, cloning a design for product piracy, or creating a targeted backdoor for stealing cryptographic keys. In many real-world settings, we have to assume a strong attacker who has full access to the IC and can analyze all hardware features therein. Numerous hardware attacks over the last few years have shown that reverse engineering is a surprisingly easy task. The goal of this project is to develop strong and quantifiable protection mechanisms for ICs. 

This interdisciplinary project combines security engineering, formal verification and circuit design, with the aim of creating strong obfuscation techniques that thwart IC reverse engineering. The approach is based on integrated circuits that perform a substantially different function than the one an attacker would infer from its physical structure. The investigators will explore a broad design space of low-level stealthy circuit manipulations and higher-level obfuscation techniques that remove structural and functional boundaries. A crucial component of the project is the development of sound metrics to measure the level of achieved security. As part of community engagement, this project envisions a De-obfuscation Challenge that will involve research groups from academia and industry.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Our world has become increasingly reliant on integrated circuits (ICs). Mobile phones are deeply enmeshed in our everyday lives, we drive cars equipped with hundreds of ICs, and have come to depend on the power grid and other cyber physical systems that are controlled by ICs. Not surprisingly, the issue of securing hardware has become increasingly important for building trust in digital systems. Quantifying the risks of reverse engineering -- which might be performed by adversaries -- and designing systems to resist reverse engineering so that they cannot be manipulated, are critically important for creating secure and trusted hardware.

Open literature has historically provided little understanding of the practical capabilities of a reverse engineer. The aim of this project has been to address this knowledge gap by holistically investigating the mental processes of humans, tooling, and algorithms of reverse engineers. Alongside this, the project simultaneously tries to leverage these findings for evaluating the security of various proposed hardware obfuscation techniques, and proposes new obfuscated designs to help slow down a reverse engineer.

The research in this project has produced significant research contributions, and associated publications in top conferences and journals. The new designs proposed in this project range from low-level circuit techniques for resisting readout of on-chip secrets, to FSM and logic designs that effectively leverage circuit-level obfuscations, and design automation techniques for creating such circuits automatically. We also triggered a new strand of research concerned with the human processes of reverse engineers.

The project has made a sustainable contribution relevant to academia, industry and government actors though the development of the open-source Hardware Analyzer tool, HAL, for hardware reverse engineering [1]. At the time when this NSF project is ending, HAL is on version 3.3.0 and is gaining broad community adoption.

A unique and notable intellectual contribution of the project has been its cross-discipline collaboration with researchers in psychology and human-machine interaction to model the cognitive processes that underlie hardware reverse engineering. We are confident that this will lead to important interdisciplinary follow-up research, bridging computer engineering and psychology.

The project has also contributed broadly to education and development through new educational modules reverse engineering, long-term student visits, and student competitions for reverse engineering and bug-finding that promote skills that are important to the US workforce.

[1]  HAL -- The Hardware Analyzer. https://github.com/emsec/hal


Last Modified: 10/14/2022
Modified by: Daniel Holcomb
